conclusion: To determine whether the distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is greater than 100 meters or less than 100 meters, we need to analyze the velocity-time graph provided.
The graph shows the vertical movement of a skydiver in the air from the moment he jumps off the aircraft until he lands. The graph is labeled as v(t) (velocity) and t (time in seconds).
The graph shows that the velocity of the skydiver increases from 0 to 20 m/s in the first 10 seconds.
After 10 seconds, the velocity decreases to 10 m/s. The skydiver then comes to a stop at 15 seconds.
The skydiver starts at rest at 0 seconds and reaches a velocity of 20 m/s at 10 seconds.
The distance fallen during this interval can be calculated using the formula: Distance = 1/2 × velocity × time.
Substituting the values: Distance = 1/2 × 20 m/s × 10 s = 100 m.
The calculated distance is 100 meters, which is exactly 100 meters.
The distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is exactly 100 meters, which is greater than 100 meters.
Final Answer: The distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is greater than 100 meters.
